Fig. 2 XRD patterns of supported catalysts after the reduction step. Crystalline phases: (•) Ni0, (♦) CaO(Al2O3)2, ( ) CaAl2O4, (♦) CaAl12O19, (♦) Al2O3 and (♦) Monoclinic ZrO2. Fig. 3 XRD patterns of promoted catalysts after the reduction step. Crystalline phases: (•) Ni0, (♦) Monoclinic ZrO2, (♦) Tetragonal ZrO2, (♦) Al2O3, ( ) CeAlO3 and (♦) CeO2. Fig. 4 Performance of supported catalysts (conversion and H2 production) in the oxidative steam reforming of HDPE pyrolysis volatiles. Reaction conditions: 700 °C, space time 3.12 gcat min gHDPE −1. Fig. 5 Individual product yields obtained in the oxidative steam reforming of HDPE pyrolysis volatiles on the supported catalysts. Reaction conditions: 700 °C, space time 3.12 gcat min gHDPE −1. Fig. 6 TPO profiles of the coke deposited on the supported catalysts. Fig. 7 TEM images of Ni/Al2O3 (a), Ni/SiO2 (b) and Ni/ZrO2 (c) used catalysts. Fig. 8 Effect of promoted catalysts on the conversion and H2 production in the oxidative steam reforming of HDPE pyrolysis volatiles. Reaction conditions: 700 °C, space time 3.12 gcat min gHDPE −1. Fig. 9 Effect of promoted catalysts on the yields of the individual products obtained in the oxidative steam reforming of HDPE pyrolysis volatiles. Box 644 - E48080 Bilbao, Spain Department of Chemical Engineering University of the Basque Country UPV/EHU P.O. Box 644 - E48080 Bilbao Spain Department of Chemical Engineering, University of the Basque Country UPV/EHU, P.O. Box 644 - E48080 Bilbao, Spain b IKERBASQUE, Basque Foundation for Science, Bilbao, Spain IKERBASQUE Basque Foundation for Science Bilbao Spain IKERBASQUE, Basque Foundation for Science, Bilbao, Spain * Corresponding author High density polyethylene (HDPE) pyrolysis and in-line oxidative steam reforming was carried out in a two-step reaction system consisting of a conical spouted bed reactor and a fluidized bed reactor. Continuous plastic pyrolysis was conducted at 550 °C and the volatiles formed were fed in-line to the oxidative steam reforming step (space-time 3.12 gcat min gHDPE −1; ER = 0.2 and steam/plastic = 3) operating at 700 °C. The influence Ni based reforming catalyst support (Al2O3, ZrO2, SiO2) and promoter (CeO2, La2O3) have on HDPE pyrolysis volatiles conversion and H2 production was assessed. The catalysts were prepared by the wet impregnation and they were characterized by means of N2 adsorption-desorption, X-ray fluorescence, temperature-programmed reduction and X-ray powder diffraction. A preliminary study on coke deposition and the deterioration of catalysts properties was carried out, by analyzing the tested catalysts through temperature programmed oxidation of coke, transmission electron microscopy, and N2 adsorption-desorption. Among the supports tested, ZrO2 showed the best performance, attaining conversion and H2 production values of 92.2% and 12.8 wt%, respectively. Concerning promoted catalysts, they led to similar conversion values (around 90%), but significant differences were observed in H2 production. Thus, higher H2 productions were obtained on the Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 catalyst (12.1 wt%) than on CeO2 promoted catalysts due to La2O3 capability for enhancing water adsorption on the catalyst surface. Graphical Abstract The influence of the support (Al2O3, ZrO2, SiO2) and the promoter (CeO2, LaO3) in the Ni-based reforming catalyst on the conversion and production of H2 in the oxidative steam reforming of HDPE pyrolysis volatiles has been evaluated. Keywords Plastic Pyrolysis Oxidative steam reforming Ni catalyst Hydrogen 1 Introduction The energy worldwide demand is mainly supplied by non-renewable sources, largely fossil fuels. Besides, energy demand is expected to increase by 48% in 20 years due to increase in population [ 1 ]. The concern for climate change, associated with the release of greenhouse gases from the excessive use of fossil fuels, led to the adoption of Paris Agreement in 2015. Thus, the goal is to hold “the increase in the global average temperature to well below 2 °C above pre-industrial levels” and pursue efforts “to limit the temperature increase to 1.5 °C above pre-industrial levels” [ 2 ]. Therefore, an energy transition from fossil fuels to non-carbon fuels is necessary, in which H2 could play a key role as energy carrier [ 3 ]. However, nowadays H2 production is mainly based on non-renewable sources, with the reforming of naphtha and CH4 accounting for 78% of H2 production [ 4,5 ]. Thereby, H2 production from alternative raw material sources, such as biomass or plastic wastes, is gaining attention. Plastic wastes are considered an interesting raw material for obtaining fuels, chemicals or H2 by thermochemical routes [ 6–8 ]. Besides, the overwhelming use of plastic materials boosted alternative plastic waste valorization routes in order to reintroduce them into the production cycle and develop a circular economy. Thus, plastics global production reached 390 million tons in 2021 and, unfortunately, 65% of post-consumer plastic wastes were used for energy recovery or landfilled in Europe [ 9 ]. Plastics are well-known for their excellent properties (lightweight, flexible, low production cost and so on), which make them essential in a daily life, but their mismanagement is causing negative impacts on natural ecosystems and human health [ 10 ]. Therefore, an adequate post-consumer plastic management has become a priority for different administrations. Accordingly, the United Nations Environment Assembly claimed the need for avoiding plastic pollution in 2022 and adopted a historical resolution to end plastic pollution and develop an international legally binding agreement by 2024 [ 11 ]. In this scenario, plastic waste valorization via H2 production may contribute to attenuating both environmental issues. Thermochemical routes for plastic waste valorization, such as pyrolysis, gasification or pyrolysis-reforming (P-SR), have been studied in the literature with the aim of obtaining fuels, chemicals, syngas or H2 [ 6,12,13 ]. Among them, plastic pyrolysis-reforming strategy is considered the most promising one for H2 production, as it allows attaining the highest H2 yields [ 7,14–18 ]. Besides, a gas stream free of tar is obtained, which is one of the main challenges of plastic steam gasification [ 12 ]. This two-step process also allows separating the catalyst from the plastic waste impurities and so minimizing its deactivation. Besides, the operating conditions in each step may be optimized independently, enhancing overall process efficiency [ 13,19 ]. However, plastic pyrolysis and in-line steam reforming for obtaining H2 has two main problems to be solved: (1) fast deactivation of the reforming catalyst; and (2) high energy requirement due to the endothermicity of the process. Ni based catalysts are widely used in CH4 steam reforming [ 20,21 ], as well as in the steam reforming of other hydrocarbons and oxygenated compounds [ 22 ], due to its high reforming activity and low cost. Apart from the active phase, the selection of a suitable support is essential for obtaining a catalyst with the required properties (thermal stability, high surface area, suitable pore distribution, mechanical strength and so on). Al2O3 is the most commonly used support for the Ni metal phase, as it confers high specific surface area and thermal stability upon the catalyst [ 23,24 ]. However, its acidity is considered responsible for promoting undesired polymerization reactions leading to coke formation [ 25–27 ]. Thus, basic supports such as MgO, ZrO2, CeO2 or La2O3 have been studied in literature in order to overcome this limitation [ 22,23 ]. Besides, it is known that redox properties and a structure with high crystalline defects provided by certain rare earth oxides (CeO2 or ZrO2) favors the oxidation of the coke deposited on the catalyst surface [ 23 ]. Similarly, ZrO2 and La2O3 supports attenuate coke deposition on the catalyst surface by enhancing steam adsorption and the gasification of coke precursors adsorbed on the catalyst surface [ 28,29 ]. Furthermore, rare earth oxides (La2O3, CeO2 or Pr6O11) and transition metal oxides (ZrO2, MnO x , or ZnO) have also been used as Ni/Al2O3 catalyst promoters as they confer suitable properties upon the catalyst, and therefore improve its performance [ 22 ]. As mentioned above, apart from fast catalyst deactivation, the endothermicity of this pyrolysis-steam reforming (P-SR) process is another shortcoming for its implementation. This issue can be solved by incorporating O2 into the reforming stage, thus providing the energy required in the reforming reactions by oxidation reactions [ 30 ]. Moreover, the addition of O2 may favor the in-situ combustion of the coke deposited on the catalyst surface, and so improve its stability [ 31,32 ]. However, O2 addition may oxidize the metal active phase, as well as promote deactivation by sintering due to the presence of hot spots caused by exothermic combustion reactions [ 20,31 ]. Besides, according to a previous thermodynamic study, H2 yield decreases as the amount of O2 introduced is increased, with this effect being more serious as the steam/plastic (S/P) ratio is increased [ 33 ]. Continuous oxidative steam reforming (OSR) of plastic wastes pyrolysis volatiles has been scarcely studied in the literature, since, to the best of our knowledge, a similar process has only been carried out by Czernik and French [ 34 ], who operated under auto-thermal conditions by introducing an air stream in the first pyrolysis step. Nevertheless, increasing attention has been paid in the recent literature to the OSR of certain compounds or streams, such as CH4 [ 35 ], diesel [ 36–38 ], gasoline [ 39,40 ] or other hydrocarbons [ 41–43 ]. In this study, pyrolysis and in line oxidative steam reforming of HDPE was conducted in a unit made up of a conical spouted bed reactor (CSBR) and a fluidized bed reactor (FBR), as this strategy has been proven to perform well for H2 production. In a previous study, the main operating conditions were optimized, with H2 production being 25.0 wt% (only 28.6% lower than that obtained in the conventional pyrolysis-steam reforming) [ 44 ]. Accordingly, the main aim of this work is to step further in the development of this process by designing a suitable catalyst for operating under oxidative reforming conditions, i.e., gain knowledge about catalysts performance in order to allow their discrimination for use in the new strategy proposed. Thus, a commercial Ni/Al2O3 catalyst and custom prepared Ni/ZrO2 and Ni/SiO2 catalysts were tested in order to analyze the effect of the support on the catalyst performance. Likewise, CeO2 and La2O3 promoted catalysts were also prepared (Ni/CeO2-Al2O3, Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 and Ni/CeO2-ZrO2) and tested in the pyrolysis-oxidative steam reforming (P-OSR). All catalysts were characterized in detail by N2 adsorption-desorption, X-ray fluorescence (XRF), temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) techniques. Therefore, the physicochemical and metal properties of the commercial and prepared catalysts have been related to performance in the P-OSR of plastics. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The raw material used is HDPE, which was supplied by Dow Chemical in the form of cylindrical pellets of 4 mm in length and 2 mm in diameter. The main HDPE features provided by the supplier are as follows: average molecular weight, 46.2 kg mol−1; polydispersity, 2.89; and density, 940 kg m−3. The higher heating value (HHV) was 43 MJ kg−1, which was determined by means of differential scanning calorimeter (Setaram TG-DSC-111) and isoperibolic bomb calorimeter (Parr 1356). ReforMax® 330 or G90LDP commercial CH4 steam reforming catalyst was supplied by Süd Chemie. The catalyst particles had a perforated ring shape (19 × 16 mm), and were ground and sieved to a suitable size (0.4–0.8 mm) for using in a fluidized bed reactor [ 45 ]. According to the supplier specifications, the NiO content of the catalyst was 14 wt% and was supported on Al2O3 doped with Ca. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis Ni/ZrO2, Ni/SiO2, Ni/CeO2-Al2O3, Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 and Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalysts were prepared with a nominal Ni content of 10 wt%. In order to operate under similar fluidization conditions, the commercial metal oxide support (ZrO2 (Alfa Aesar), as well as SiO2 (Merk) and γ-Al2O3 (Alfa Aesar)), were ground and sieved to a suitable particle size depending on their difference in density. Thus, the size ranges used were 0.40–0.63 mm for ZrO2 support, 0.63–1.00 mm for SiO2 support and 0.40–0.80 mm for Al2O3 support. Then, they were fluidized for several hours for improving their mechanical strength prior to Ni impregnation. Additionally, γ-Al2O3 support was calcined at 1000 °C for 5 h to obtain a thermally stable support. All the catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation, which was carried out in a rotary evaporator (Büchi rotavapor R-114) that operates under vacuum at 70 °C. In the case of promoted catalysts, prior to loading the Ni, the supports (ZrO2 and γ-Al2O3) were modified by impregnation in aqueous solutions (10 mL of solution per g of support) containing the metal salt precursors of La(NO3)3·6H2O or Ce(NO3)2·6H2O. The concentration of the promoter oxide in the support was fixed at 10 wt%. The modified supports were dried overnight and calcined at 900 °C for 3 h. Ni was then impregnated onto the support with an aqueous solution (10 mL of solution per g of support) of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (VWR Chemicals, 99%). All the catalysts were prepared with a nominal Ni content of 10 wt% in the final catalysts. Finally, the prepared catalysts were dried overnight and calcined at 700 °C for 3 h. 2.3 Catalyst characterization N2 adsorption-desorption at cryogenic temperature (Micromeritics ASAP 2010) was used to determine the physical properties of the catalysts. The data obtained from N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms allowed calculating the BET surface area, pore volume distribution and average pore size of the catalysts based on BET equation and BJH method. H2-TPR was carried out in an Autochem II 2920 Micromeritics. TPR analyses were carried out from room temperature to 900 °C (heating rate of 5 °C min−1) in a H2 stream diluted in Ar (10 vol% of H2). Previously, the catalysts were thermally treated under a He stream at 200 °C in order to remove water or any other impurity. Thereby, the reduction temperature of the metal phase in each catalyst was determined. The total Ni load was determined by means of sequential wavelength dispersion XRF in a spectrometer (Axios 2005, PANalytical). Furthermore, the crystalline structure of the reduced catalysts was determined by XRD in a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer. These analyses were carried out in the central services (SGIker) at the University of the Basque Country (UPV/EHU). The coke deposited on the catalysts after the catalytic runs (i.e., for a reaction time of 30 min) was characterized by TPO in a thermobalance (TGA Q5000 TA Instruments), by the following procedure: (1) stripping with N2 (50 mL min–1) at 200 °C for 20 min, for moisture removal; (2) switching N2 to air (50 mL min–1), after decreasing the temperature to 100 °C, and stabilization for 5 min; (3) coke oxidation by rising temperature to 800 °C (with a heating rate of 5 °C min–1) and keeping it for 30 min, in order to guarantee total coke combustion. It is to note that the mass loss observed in the TPO analyses, associated with the combustion of coke, was influenced by the mass gain occurring due to the oxidation of the Ni0 active phase of the catalysts. Therefore, the mass gain corresponding to each catalyst was previously measured by conducting TPO analyses of the fresh reduced catalysts. Accordingly, the amount of coke contained in each catalyst was determined by subtracting the final sample mass from the initial one and considering the oxidation of the metal phase. In addition, TEM was employed to study the nature and location of the coke deposited on the catalysts (Philips CM200). These analyses were carried out in the central services (SGIker) at the University of the Basque Country (UPV/EHU). 2.4 Experimental equipment and operating conditions Plastic P-OSR runs were carried out in a laboratory bench scale unit described in a previous work [ 44 ]. Plastic pyrolysis was carried out in a CSBR and the volatiles formed were fed in-line into a FBR. The excellent performance of this two-step system for pyrolysis-steam reforming of biomass and plastics has already been proven in previous studies [ 45–47 ]. The plastic was continuously fed (1 g min−1) into the pyrolysis reactor by means of a custom-built feeding system. Thus, the plastic is loaded into a cylindrical vessel, in which a piston located at the bottom is lifted, and the plastic overflows into the reactor through a pipe cooled by tap water. The pyrolysis reaction was carried out at 550 °C in a CSBR equipped with a non-porous draft tube containing 75 g of sand in the 0.2–0.3 mm particle size. The CSBR and the gas preheater are located within a radiant oven, which provides the heat required to reach the reaction temperature. The vigorous solid movement and the high heat and mass transfer rates in the CSBR are features that allow: (1) avoiding bed defluidization caused by particle agglomeration [ 48 ] and (2) ensuring a homogenous gas composition at the outlet of the first step, which is essential for an accurate assessment of the second step performance [ 49 ]. Besides, the draft tube improves bed stability and allows operating with lower gas flow rates [ 50,51 ]. Both the reactor and the draft tube were designed based on previous hydrodynamic studies and their dimensions were reported elsewhere [ 52,53 ]. Steam (3 mL min−1 of water) was used as fluidizing agent rather than N2, as it is inert at the low pyrolysis temperature used, and avoids the outlet stream dilution. Thus, a steam/plastic (S/P) ratio of 3 was used, which was established in a previous study in order to strike a balance between maximum H2 production and minimum energy consumption associated with water vaporization [ 44 ]. The conditions attained in the CSBR ensure the polymer degradation under fast pyrolysis conditions. Therefore, the pyrolysis reactor led to a continuous volatile stream composed of 60.9 wt% of waxes, 30 wt% of C12–C21, 6.7 wt% of C5–C11 and 2.4 wt% of C1–C4. These compounds were transferred in line into the reforming reactor, and no solid residue remained in the pyrolysis reactor. Therefore, the elemental composition of the volatile stream is the same as that of the HDPE in the feed. This volatile stream was fed into the FBR for its OSR on different reforming catalysts. A reforming temperature of 700 °C was selected, since higher temperatures led to irreversible catalyst deactivation by Ni sintering [ 44 ]. Likewise, O2 flow rate was selected based on previous studies, in which an equivalence ratio (ER) of 0.2 corresponding to autothermal operation was selected as the optimum one to account for the energy requirements of the reforming reaction [ 33,44 ]. The O2 was fed into the FBR by means of a multi-point diffusor, which allows a homogenous distribution of O2 into the bed, and avoids: (1) the oxidation of the volatile stream prior to entering the reactor; and (2) hot spot formation and the consequent catalyst deactivation by Ni sintering or oxidation. The space-time selected to study the performance of different catalysts was 3.12 gcat min gHDPE −1, which is that ensuring kinetic control in the runs. It is to note that the space-time is defined as the ratio between the reforming catalyst mass and the volatiles mass flow rate entering the reforming reactor, which is equal to the HDPE mass flow rate fed to the system due to the complete degradation of the plastic in the pyrolysis step. Moreover, the bed in the FBR was composed of 25 g of a mixture of reforming catalyst and sand (0.4–0.8 and 0.3–0.35 mm size ranges for the catalyst and sand, respectively). The catalysts were reduced prior to the reforming process by in-situ reduction at 710 °C for 4 h under H2 stream (10 vol%) diluted with N2. The FBR was also placed inside a radiant oven to provide the heat required to reach the reforming temperature. Both reactors (CSBR and FBR) were placed inside a convection oven to avoid the condensation of both the pyrolysis volatile stream entering the reforming step and the reforming product stream to be injected into the gas chromatograph (GC). A gas cleaning system is arranged as follows: (1) a sintered steel filter to collect the entrained catalyst particles; (2) a condenser cooled with tap water; and, (3) two coalescence filters to ensure that the permanent gases are fully cleaned prior to injecting into the GC. Prior to gas product condensation, a sample of the reformed product stream was driven through a thermostated line (280 °C) for its analysis in an Agilent GC-6890 equipped with a HP-Pona column and flame ionization detector (FID). The permanent gases were collected in a Tedlar gas-sampling bag and analyzed off-line in an Agilent 4900 micro-GC, which is equipped with three analytical modules (MS5A, Plot-Q and Plot-Al2O3) and their corresponding thermal conductivity detectors (TCD). Prior product analysis, each experiment was conducted for 10 min (in order to guarantee steady state operation). A detailed analysis of the products obtained was accomplished, with reproducibility being ensured by repeating the runs at least 3 times under the same conditions. 2.5 Reaction indices Reaction indices (carbon conversion, carbon containing gaseous product yields, H2 yield and H2 production) were defined in order to quantify the performance of the different catalysts prepared. Thus, carbon conversion in the reforming reactor was defined as the ratio between the C moles in the gaseous reformed product stream (C Gas) and the C moles in the HDPE pyrolysis volatile stream (C volatiles). As mentioned above, no solid residue remained in the CSBR during the pyrolysis step, and therefore both the flow rate and the elemental composition of the pyrolysis volatile stream are the same as those of the HDPE fed into the system. (1) X = C Gas/C Volatiles × 100% Regarding the yield of any carbon containing gaseous product, it was defined as follows: (2) Y i = F i/F Volatiles × 100% where F i is the molar flow rate of any carbon containing gaseous product and F volatiles the molar flow rate of the HDPE pyrolysis volatile stream fed into the reforming step. Moreover, the H2 yield was defined as the ratio between the actual H2 molar flow rate (F H2) and the maximum H2 molar flow rate allowable by stoichiometry (F 0 H2): (3) Y H2 = F H2/F 0 H2 × 100% where the following stoichiometry was considered for the OSR of HDPE pyrolysis volatiles: (4) C n H m + αO2 + (2n–2α)H2O → nCO2 + (2n–2α + m/2)H2 Additionally, H2 production was quantified as the ratio between the H2 mass flow rates produced (m H2) and the HDPE mas flow rate (m HDPE) fed into the process: (5) Prod.H2 = m H2/m HDPE × 100% 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Fresh catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Physical properties and composition The textural properties (BET surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter), Ni content and metal dispersion of the catalysts are shown in Table 1 . It can be seen that the BET surface area decreased when Ni was impregnated on the catalyst supports, and this value was even lower when the promoter was impregnated prior to Ni. This trend may be attributed to the blockage of the support pores by both the promoter and Ni, making them inaccessible for N2 adsorption [ 54,55 ]. Besides, according to the literature, the addition of low metal oxide loads onto the support does not have any effect on the catalyst textural properties [ 56 ], but an excess of La2O3 or CeO2 may block the porous structure of the support [ 57,58 ]. As observed, the BET surface area decreased from 97 to 34 m2 g−1 when Ni was impregnated on the ZrO2 support and to 29 m2 g−1 in case of CeO2 promoted Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst. Likewise, CeO2 and La2O3 promoted Ni/Al2O3 catalysts show a decrease in their surface area from 87 to 66 and 52 m2 g−1, respectively. It is remarkable the high surface area (429 m2 g−1) and small average pore diameter (53 Å) of the Ni/SiO2 catalyst, which is attributable to the high microporosity of the SiO2 support used (numerous micropores together with a few meso- and macropores), with its surface area and pore diameter being 703 m2 g−1 and 45 Å, respectively. It is well-known the significance of using a support with high surface area, as it favors the dispersion of the Ni active phase on the catalyst support, and therefore the formation of smaller Ni metal particles [ 59,60 ]. Accordingly, Ni dispersion decreases as follows: Ni/SiO2 > Ni/CeO2-Al2O3 > Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 > Ni/ZrO2 = commercial Ni/Al2O3 > Ni/CeO2-ZrO2, which is consistent with the decrease in the values of BET surface area. Regarding the Ni metal content of the catalysts, although all the catalysts were prepared to obtain a Ni0 content of 10 wt%, significant differences are observed. The Ni contents of the supported catalysts (Ni/ZrO2 and Ni/SiO2) are close to the expected value (9.5 wt%), but those of the promoted catalysts are significantly lower. Thus, the Ni content of CeO2 and La2O3 promoted Ni/Al2O3 catalysts was 8.1 wt% and even lower in the case of Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst (6.6 wt%). It seems that the lower Ni content obtained is due to the low surface area of promoted supports and the low pore volume of CeO2 promoted ZrO2 support, which may inhibit a homogeneous impregnation of Ni on the catalyst support. 3.1.2 Reducibility of metal species Fig. 1 shows the H2-TPR profiles of the commercial Ni/Al2O3, and those of the prepared Ni/ZrO2 and Ni/SiO2 supported catalysts (Fig. 1(a)), as well as those of Ni/CeO2-Al2O3, Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 and Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 promoted catalysts (Fig. 1(b)), in which the role of the support in the reducibility of the metal phase is clearly observed. Regarding the commercial Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, two main peaks are observed at 500 and 700 °C, associated with NiO interacting with Al2O3 support and Ni integrated into the NiAl2O4 spinel phase, respectively [ 62,63 ]. It should be noted that a small peak can also be observed at low temperature (250 °C), related to NiO weakly interacting with the Al2O3 support. The TPR curve of the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst shows a weak interaction of NiO with the ZrO2 support, as there are two main peaks below 500 °C (300 and 450 °C) [ 64,65 ]. Concerning the Ni/SiO2 catalyst, a very broad peak from 320 to 750 °C can be observed. The main peak at 550 °C is related to Ni strongly interacting with the SiO2 support, whereas lower temperature shoulders (360 and 480 °C) are evidence of the presence of Ni weakly interacting with the support [ 66,67 ]. Regarding promoted catalysts, the reduction temperature for Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst is below 500 °C, which is also the case for the unpromoted Ni/ZrO2 catalyst. This is evidence that CeO2 promoter does not favor stronger metal-support interactions. Furthermore, CeO2 and La2O3 promoted Ni/Al2O3 catalysts have strong metal-support interactions. Accordingly, the Ni/CeO2-Al2O3 catalyst shows three main peaks at 550, 710 and 815 °C. The peak at 550 °C is related to NiO strongly interacting with CeO2-Al2O3 support and the peak at 710 °C is associated with the Ni integrated into NiAl2O4 spinel phase. Moreover, a low intensity peak associated with the weak interaction of NiO with the CeO2-Al2O3 support can be observed at 400 °C. It is to note that previous studies revealed that the presence of CeO2 in Ni/Al2O3 catalysts weakens the metal-support interaction, thereby improving the reducibility of the promoted catalyst [ 68 ]. Besides, the reduction peak at high temperatures (> 800 °C) is evidence of the reduction of bulk ceria crystallites due to the formation of CeAlO3 [ 69 ]. Regarding Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 catalyst, it shows the highest reduction temperature, which is evidence of a strong metal-support interaction in this catalyst. Thus, the peak at 690 °C is associated with NiO species strongly interacting with La2O3-Al2O3 support and the peak at 780 °C is attributed to Ni integrated into NiAl2O4 spinel phase, with both temperatures being higher than those observed for the CeO2 promoted Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. In addition, a peak related to NiO weakly interacting with the support is barely appreciated at 450 °C. This effect is related, on the one hand, to the different nature of NiAl2O4 spinel phase, since NiAl2O4 spinel hosting octahedral Ni2+ sites are more reducible than tetrahedral ones, and, on the other hand, to the formation of other mixed phases such as perovskite-type LaAl1–x Ni x O3 [ 70 ]. 3.1.3 Metal properties Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of the commercial Ni/Al2O3 and synthesized Ni/ZrO2 and Ni/SiO2 supported catalysts. It is to note that these XRD analysis were carried out to the reduced catalysts, with the reduction step being conducted at 710 °C for 4 h under H2 stream (10 vol%) diluted with N2. As observed, the diffraction peaks are related to the crystalline phase determined by the ICDD's Powder Diffraction File [ 71 ]. Thus, the three patterns show diffraction peaks of the Ni0 metal phase at 2θ = 44.6°, 52.0° and 76.5° assigned to the planes (111), (200) and (220). Furthermore, the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 37.2°, 43.3° and 63.0° corresponding to NiO are not detected, which is evidence they are fully reduced. Regarding Ni/Al2O3 commercial catalyst, a strong interaction between Al2O3 and CaO (this catalysts is doped with CaO) is confirmed, with Al2O3 diffraction peaks being hardly detected, i.e., small diffraction peaks at 2θ = 35.4°, 45.3° and 67.3° are observed. Besides, although typical diffraction peaks related to CaAl2O4 (2θ = 30.1°, 32.8°, 34.2°, 36.9°, 37.7°, 39.4°, 41.4° and 43.3°) are observed, those corresponding to CaO(Al2O3)2 (2θ = 14.4°, 20.0°, 24.6°, 25.6°, 32.8°, 34.5°, 35.4°, 37.7°, 39.4°, 41.4°, 43.3°, 57.4° and 60.3°) and CaAl12O19 (2θ = 34.2°, 36.2°, 37.7°, 39.4°, 41.4°, 50.6°, 57.4° and 60.3°) are evidence of a strong interaction between support species in the commercial catalyst. Concerning Ni/ZrO2 catalyst, apart from Ni0 phase diffraction lines, those related to ZrO2 monoclinic structure are observed at 2θ = 17.7°, 24.4°, 28.5°, 31.7°, 34.5°, 35.6°, 38.8°, 41°, 44.8°, 49.6°, 50.5°, 54.5°, 55.7°, 60.2°, 61.5°, 63.1°, 65.9°, 71.5°. Finally, Ni/SiO2 catalyst shows a broad peak from 2θ =15° to 30°, revealing the poor crystallinity of the siliceous material. Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of promoted Ni/CeO2-Al2O3, Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 and Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalysts. Similarly to the supported catalysts, the promoted ones have also been fully reduced and only Ni0 phase is observed (2θ = 44.6°, 52.0° and 76.5°), i.e., no presence of NiO phase (2θ = 37.2°, 43.3° and 63.0°). As regards the Ni/CeO2-Al2O3 catalyst, apart from the Ni0 phase diffraction lines, those related to the crystalline phases of CeO2 fluorite structure (2θ = 28.8°, 33.1°, 47.7°, 56.6°, 76.7°) and Al2O3 (2θ = 31.7°, 37°, 39.7°, 47.7°, 60.1°, 67.9°) are observed. The presence of the fluorite structure of CeO2 is related to the good dispersion of cerium on the Al2O3 surface [ 57 ]. Besides, CeAlO3 spinel phase diffraction lines are identified at 2θ = 23°, 44°, 47° and 60°, presumably formed when the catalyst was reduced. In fact, CeAlO3 spinel formation is a consequence of the solid-state reaction between Ce2O3 and Al2O3 above 600 °C, with Ce2O3 being the product of partially reduced CeO2 under H2 atmosphere [ 72 ]. Concerning the Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 catalyst, no lanthanum crystalline species (La2O3, LaAlO3) are detected, which is evidence of the poor crystallinity of La2O3. The formation of LaAlO3 spinel phase requires a solid-state reaction between La2O3 and Al2O3, which is enhanced by increasing lanthanum content and calcination temperature [ 73 ]. Regarding the Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst, the absence of Ce species in the XRD diffractogram is noteworthy, which may be explained by their low crystallinity or small crystallite size. Moreover, unlike the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst, Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 one shows diffraction peaks of ZrO2 corresponding to the tetragonal crystalline phase (2θ = 30.2°, 34.5°, 35.3°, 50.1°, 60.0°, 62.8°, and 81.6°). It seems that the presence of CeO2 as promoter attenuates the transformation of tetragonal zirconium phase into monoclinic phase during catalyst calcination (700 °C). It is known that the tetragonal phase of zirconia is not stable above 600 °C, and similar trends are observed for La-doped Ni/ZrO2 catalyst, in which high lanthanum contents stabilized tetragonal ZrO2 phase [ 65 ]. 3.2 Effect of the support on the catalytic performance 3.2.1 Catalytic tests results Fig. 4 shows the conversion and H2 production values obtained using different supported catalysts in the HDPE pyrolysis volatiles OSR at 700 °C. It is to note that, due to the low space-time used (3.12 gcat min gHDPE −1), carbon conversion values lower than 100% have been obtained for all the catalysts studied. Nevertheless, full conversion may be attained with all of them by increasing space time. In fact, previous results showed that almost full conversion was attained by increasing the space time to 12.5 gcat min gHDPE −1 when the Ni/Al2O3 commercial catalyst was used, i.e., a H2 production of 25 wt% was attained [ 44 ]. In order to analyze the performance of the different catalysts, the following reactions occurring in the reforming stage were considered: Steam reforming of hydrocarbons: (6) Hydrocarbons + H2O → CO + H2 WGS: (7) CO + H2O ↔ CO2 + H2 CH4 steam reforming: (8) CH4 + H2O ↔ CO + 3H2 Hydrocarbons dry reforming: (9) Hydrocarbons + CO2 → CO + H2 CH4 dry reforming: (10) CH4 + CO2 ↔ 2CO + 2H2 Hydrocarbons oxidation: (11) Hydrocarbons + O2 → CO2 + H2O H2 oxidation: (12) H 2 + 1 2 O 2 → H 2 O CO oxidation: (13) CO + 1 2 O 2 → CO 2 CH4 oxidation: (14) CH4 + 2O2 → CO2 + 2H2O As observed in Fig. 4, among the three supported catalysts studied the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst leads to the highest carbon conversion (92.2%), as well as the highest H2 production (12.8 wt%). Therefore, although the Ni content of the prepared catalyst is somewhat lower (9.5 wt% for Ni/ZrO2 and 11.3 wt% for Ni/Al2O3 respectively) (Table 1), the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst leads to better results than those with the Ni/Al2O3 commercial one. In fact, the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst was fully reduced at the reduction temperature established (710 °C) (Fig. 1), and therefore all the Ni0 active sites are available for the reforming reaction. Nevertheless, concerning the commercial Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, the Ni integrated into the NiAl2O4 spinel phase was not fully reduced at 710 °C, with the amount of active Ni0 for reforming reactions being lower than its oxidized Ni content calculated by XRF. Moreover, lower carbon conversion (85.1%) and H2 production (1.1 wt%) were obtained when Ni/SiO2 catalyst was used in the HDPE pyrolysis-OSR process. Although the best dispersion value was attained in the Ni/SiO2 catalyst (8.8%), it seems that its surface properties are not suitable enough for the OSR of HDPE pyrolysis volatiles, since its microporosity may have hindered the accessibility and diffusion of the reactants onto Ni0 active sites. It is to note that polyethylene pyrolysis products are mainly made up of bulky molecules, such as waxes and heavy hydrocarbons in the diesel range. The poor performance of the Ni/SiO2 catalyst due to its unsuitable textural properties was also reported in previous studies dealing with biomass pyrolysis and in line steam reforming [ 47 ]. It is to note that the support plays an important role in the OSR reaction mechanism. In fact, the adsorption and activation of O2 species are essential steps in the mechanism of hydrocarbons reforming, in which the nature of the support is a key factor [ 74 ]. Thus, supports with redox properties and O2 vacancies, such as ZrO2, favor the adsorption of O2 intermediates, and therefore enhance the reforming reaction. However, when neutral supports like SiO2 are used, Ni metal sites control the formation of intermediates involving hydrocarbon species, as well as the formation of intermediates involving O2 species, which generally lead to lower catalytic activity [ 74 ]. Fig. 5 shows the yields of the individual products obtained in the OSR of HDPE pyrolysis volatiles on different supported catalysts. As observed, similar yields have been obtained on Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/ZrO2 catalysts, with H2, CO2 and CO yields being slightly higher when the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst was used, i.e., 36.2% vs. 37.7%, 37.1% vs. 38% and 19.7% vs. 21.2%, respectively. Therefore, the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst shows slightly higher activity for steam reforming (Eqs. (6) and (8)) and WGS reactions (Eq. (7)) than Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. A higher activity of Ni/ZrO2 catalyst compared with other Ni based supported catalysts was also observed in the steam reforming of biomass pyrolysis volatiles [ 47 ], which may be attributed to the suitable surface properties of the ZrO2 support. It is known that ZrO2 support has better redox properties, and therefore enhances steam adsorption [ 23,75 ], which favors steam reforming and WGS reactions by increasing not only carbon conversion, but also H2 production. In fact, the redox properties of the catalyst support play a key role in the OSR reaction, since several oxidation-reduction cycles occur on the catalyst surface. This redox process follows Mars-Vam Krevelen reaction mechanism [ 76 ], in which O2 mobility and a high number of crystalline defects (O2 vacancies) in the ZrO2 support are essential facts [ 23 ]. The low yields of H2, CO2 and CO obtained on Ni/SiO2 catalyst (3.2%, 16.4% and 10.3%, respectively) are evidence of the poor activity of this catalyst for reforming reactions. Besides, in line with the previous conversion values (Fig. 4), C5+ yield is remarkably higher (14.8%) than that obtained on the commercial Ni/Al2O3 catalyst and on the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst. Likewise, the high yield of C2–C4 gaseous products obtained (54.2%) on the Ni/SiO2 catalyst, is evidence that secondary cracking reactions take place in the absence of reforming ones, leading to gaseous hydrocarbon products. Therefore, the microporosity of this catalyst hinders the accessibility and diffusion of the reactants onto the Ni active phase, and therefore the transformation of the reactants is partially produced by thermal cracking at the selected reforming temperature (700 °C). Huang et al. [ 77 ] also observed poor activity of Ni/SiO2 catalyst in the reforming of LDPE pyrolysis volatiles on different supported catalysts (Al2O3, MgO, CeO2, Y2O3, TiO2, SiO2 and ZSM-5). The lower activity of Ni/SiO2 catalyst was attributed to the low metal-support interaction in the prepared catalyst and the high reforming temperature used (800 °C), at which Ni oxidation by steam may also occur. 3.2.2 Characterization of tested supported catalysts Fig. 6 shows the TPO curves of the coke deposited on the tested catalysts (Ni/Al2O3, Ni/SiO2 and Ni/ZrO2). On the one hand, it can be observed that the coke deposited on the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst is burnt within a narrower temperature range than the coke deposited on both Ni/SiO2 and Ni/ZrO2. This difference denotes the deposition of a more homogeneous coke on Ni/Al2O3, both in terms of its nature and location. On the other hand, in the case of Ni/SiO2 and Ni/ZrO2, coke combustion initiates at lower temperatures, which evidences the deposition of an amorphous or encapsulating coke. In fact, the differences observed in the TPO profiles can be related to [ 26,78,79 ]: (1) coke location, as the coke encapsulating the Ni active sites is burnt at lower temperatures than the one deposited on the surface (the combustion of the latter will not be catalytically activated by the metal sites); and, (2) coke nature, since amorphous coke (with a higher H/C ratio) has lower combustion temperatures than structured or filamentous coke (with a lower H/C ratio). The TPO analysis allows determining the amount of coke deposited on each tested catalyst. In order to compare the values obtained on different reaction conditions, the average coke deposition rate has been established, which is defined as follows: (15) R coke = (W coke/t)/(W cat × m HDPE) where W coke and W cat are coke and catalyst masses respectively, t is the time on stream and m HDPE is the plastic feed rate. Table 2 shows the amount of coke, together with the reaction time and the average coke deposition rate for each of the catalysts. As observed, the catalyst with the highest coke deposition rate is Ni/ZrO2 (0.64 mgcoke gcat −1 gHDPE −1), followed by Ni/Al2O3 (0.65 mgcoke gcat −1 gHDPE −1) and Ni/SiO2 (0.26 mgcoke gcat −1 gHDPE −1). It is to be highlighted that in this study, the conversions attained when Ni/ZrO2 and Ni/Al2O3 were used are very similar (Fig. 4), which implies a similar composition of the reaction medium, and therefore an analogous concentration of coke precursors (non-converted hydrocarbons [ 78 ]). Therefore, the coke deposition rate is almost equal for these two catalysts. However, the lower coke deposition rate observed for Ni/SiO2, in which the concentration of coke precursors is higher (lower conversion is attained), could be related to the microporosity of this catalyst. Taking into account that coke formation is initiated by the carbonaceous species adsorbed on Ni metal sites [ 26 ], its deposition over the Ni/SiO2 catalyst could be hindered by the poor accessibility and diffusion of the reactants onto Ni active sites. Table 2 also displays the textural properties of the tested catalysts. The three catalysts show a significant deterioration in their physical properties, with a considerable decrease of the BET area as a result of the blocking of the catalyst surface by coke deposition. Regarding the average pore size, it can be established that, in the case of Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/SiO2 catalysts, coke largely blocks their smaller pores, which led to an increase in their average pore size. However, in the case of Ni/ZrO2, the average pore size decreases due to the fact that in this catalyst the coke is mainly deposited on its largest pores. Fig. 7 shows the TEM images of the used Ni/Al2O3, Ni/SiO2 and Ni/ZrO2 catalysts, where different zones can be distinguished: (1) dark areas, corresponding to Ni active sites; (2) encapsulating coke deposited on the Ni active sites; and (3) filamentous carbonaceous material. It is known that in the reforming of HDPE pyrolysis volatiles, filamentous coke is preferentially formed, which grows in length and diameter as time on stream increases [ 78 ]. TEM images show that in the supported catalysts tested, only the formation of a nascent filamentous and encapsulating coke took place, presumably due to the low time on stream used (30 min). These results corroborate the ones observed in the TPO profiles (Fig. 6), with Ni/Al2O3 being the catalysts in which more filamentous coke is formed (higher combustion temperature). However, the coke deposited over Ni/ZrO2, and mainly Ni/SiO2, is a more amorphous coke, mostly deposited over the Ni metal sites. 3.3 Effect of the promoter on the catalytic performance 3.3.1 Catalytic tests results Fig. 8 shows the carbon conversion and H2 production values obtained in the OSR of HDPE pyrolysis volatiles on different promoted catalysts. As observed, similar conversion values are attained on all the catalysts, i.e., 90.5%, 90.0% and 89.4% for Ni/CeO2-ZrO2, Ni/CeO2-Al2O3 and Ni/La2O3-Al2O3, respectively. It should be noted that the conversion values are lower than those obtained on the supported Ni/ZrO2 catalyst (92.2%) and commercial Ni/Al2O3 one (91.1%) (Fig. 4), which is presumably due to the lower Ni content of the promoted ones (Table 1). Moreover, not only the effective Ni load (determined by XRF analysis), but also the reducibility of each catalyst play a key role in the initial conversion in the HDPE pyrolysis-OSR. Thus, despite the low Ni content in the Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst (6.6 wt%), a high conversion was attained (90.5%), which is attributed to the low reduction temperature of this catalyst. In fact, at the selected reduction temperature (710 °C), all the Ni is reduced, and it is therefore in the metal state in the reforming reactor. Conversely, full NiO reduction is not attained at 710 °C for neither Ni/CeO2-Al2O3 nor Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 catalysts due to the formation of a spinel phase, which involves a higher reduction temperature of part of the Ni. Therefore, after the catalyst reduction pretreatment, the available Ni0 active sites in the promoted Ni/Al2O3 catalysts are lower than in the Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst, leading to slightly lower conversion values of 90.0% on Ni/CeO2-Al2O3 and 89.4% on Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 catalysts, respectively. Farooq et al. [ 80 ] also observed a good performance of the Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst in the reforming of the LDPE gasification volatile stream in a two-step reactor system. Ni/Al2O3, Ni/ZrO2 and Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalysts were tested in a fixed bed reforming reactor, with the highest gas yield (67%) and H2 yield (9.3 wt%) being attained on the Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst [ 80,81 ]. The good performance of this catalyst was attributed to its redox properties and O2 vacancies promoted by CeO2 inclusion onto the ZrO2 support. The good characteristics of ZrO2 should also be remarked, since the amphoteric character of this support provides both acid and basic properties to the catalyst, improving not only Ni dispersion onto the catalyst support by Lewis acid sites, but also the adsorption of O2 species on basic sites [ 82 ]. Besides, the poor thermal stability of CeO2 support is attenuated using a CeO2-ZrO2 support [ 54 ]. According to Zhou et al. [ 64 ], Ce/Zr molar ratio should be carefully controlled, since it may affect the thermal stability, structure, textural properties and surface chemical states of the supports, and therefore its catalytic performance. Regarding H2 production, Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 leads to the highest H2 production (12.1 wt%), which is similar to those obtained with supported Ni/ZrO2 (12.8 wt%) and commercial Ni/Al2O3 (12.5 wt%) catalysts. In spite of the lower conversion obtained with Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 (89.4%), presumably due to its lower amount of available Ni0 active sites, the high H2 production obtained reveals the higher activity of this catalyst for WGS reaction. It is known that use of La2O3 as promoter enhances the water adsorption capability of the catalyst, and therefore favors WGS reaction leading to higher H2 production [ 22,28 ]. Ni/CeO2-Al2O3 and Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalysts lead to similar H2 production values (10.5 wt% and 10.2 wt%, respectively), which are slightly lower than those obtained on supported Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/ZrO2 catalysts (12.5 wt% and 12.8 wt%, respectively). Moreover, despite the lower initial performance of CeO2 promoted catalysts in terms of H2 production, this promoter is considered a promising material for improving stability due to its capacity for avoiding catalyst deactivation by in-situ gasification of coke deposits [ 35,83,84 ]. The yields of individual products obtained in the oxidative steam reforming of HDPE pyrolysis volatiles on Ni/CeO2-Al2O3, Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 and Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 9 . As observed, higher H2 and CO2 yields are obtained on the Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 catalyst (34.9% and 35.5%) than those obtained on Ni/CeO2-Al2O3 (31.3% and 34.5%) and Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 (30.7% and 35.1%) catalysts. However, similar yields of CH4 (around 3%), C2-C4 (around 31%) and C5+ (around 10%) are attained on all promoted catalysts. Therefore, the three promoted catalysts have similar activity for hydrocarbons reforming, but the Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 catalyst leads to the highest activity for WGS reaction, and therefore enhances H2 and CO2 formation. It is noteworthy that the high hydrocarbon yield obtained is a due to the low space-time used in this study. In fact, the system proposed may lead to full conversion in the steam reforming and oxidative steam reforming of plastics and biomass pyrolysis volatiles [ 44,52,85,86 ]. The good performance of Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 catalyst for enhancing WGS reaction was also observed in the steam reforming of polypropylene (PP) pyrolysis volatile stream on the prepared catalysts (Ni/Al2O3, Ni/CeO2-Al2O3, and Ni/La2O3-Al2O3) [ 84 ]. In fact, H2 productions of 34.9 wt% and 24.9 wt% were attained when space-times of 16.7 and 4.1 gcat min gPP −1 were used, respectively. Likewise, Czernik and French [ 34 ] studied PP pyrolysis and steam reforming of the volatile stream on a commercial catalyst in a two-step fluidized bed system in continuous mode, and they obtained similar H2 production values (34.2 wt%). Namioka et al. [ 87 ] also carried out PP pyrolysis-reforming in continuous mode obtaining a slightly higher H2 productions (36 wt%). It is to note that the lower H2 productions obtained in the present P-OSR process than in the conventional pyrolysis-steam reforming process is not only due to the low space-time used, but also to the feed of O2 into the reforming reactor, which favors oxidation reactions (Eqs. (11)–(14)). In spite of this fact, H2 productions higher than 10 wt% are attained under autothermal conditions on all the promoted catalysts tested. However, a previous study proved that an initial H2 production of 25 wt% may be attained on a commercial Ni/Al2O3 catalyst when operation was conducted under optimum conditions in the OSR step, i.e., a space time of 12.5 gcat min gHDPE −1 with the remaining operating conditions being the same as those used in this study (reforming temperature of 700 °C, ER of 0.2 and S/P ratio of 3) [ 44 ]. Similar H2 productions were obtained by Czernik and French [ 34 ] in the PP pyrolysis-steam reforming under autothermal operation (24 wt%). Thus, P-OSR has proven to be a suitable strategy for H2 production, leading to considerably higher values than those obtained with the alternative plastic waste steam gasification [ 12,88–90 ]. 3.3.2 Characterization of tested promoted catalysts The promoted catalysts used have been characterized by TPO, TEM and N2 absorption-desorption, in order to carry out a preliminary study on coke deposition. Fig. 10 shows the TPO profiles of the cokes deposited on Ni/CeO2-Al2O3, Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 and Ni/CeO2-ZrO2, where it can be observed the formation of a heterogeneous coke with a broad TPO profile between 200–600 °C, over the three catalysts. Specifically, both CeO2 promoted catalysts show three different peaks at approximately 300, 450 and 600 °C. On the one hand, the two peaks at low temperatures are related to encapsulating or amorphous coke, presumably deposited on different locations, and whose oxidation is activated by the CeO2 promoter and the Ni active sites [ 68,84 ]. On the other hand, the peak observed at high temperature is associated with the formation of filamentous coke [ 78 ], with this peak being the prevailing one in the case of the Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst. Regarding the coke deposited over Ni/La2O3-Al2O3, its TPO profile shows a main peak at 480 °C and a smaller one at lower temperatures. As aforementioned, the difference between the cokes associated to these two peaks is related to both the nature and the location of the coke deposited [ 26 ]. In addition, a small shoulder can be observed at 580 °C, which presumably indicates a slight deposition of filamentous coke. Table 3 shows the coke amount and average coke deposition rate on each catalyst tested. It can be seen that the La2O3 promoted catalyst shows a higher coke deposition rate (0.61 mgcoke gcat −1 gHDPE −1) than the CeO2 promoted Ni/CeO2-Al2O3 (0.36 mgcoke gcat −1 gHDPE −1) and Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 (0.40 mgcoke gcat −1 gHDPE −1) catalysts. This trend could be explained by the lower conversion attained over the Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 8), which gives way to a higher concentration of coke precursors in the reaction medium, resulting in a higher coke deposition rate. However, it is to note that the use of La2O3 as promoter attenuates coke deposition on the reforming catalyst. Indeed, if these results are compared to the coke deposition rates achieved with the supported catalysts (Table 2), it can be seen that similar rates are obtained even though the concentration of coke precursors in the reaction medium was higher for Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 (i.e., lower conversion values). In fact, it is known that the presence of La2O3 favors water adsorption and so the subsequent gasification of the incipient coke, minimizing its deposition and evolution to more condensed structures [ 28,84 ]. Regarding the CeO2 promoted catalysts, it is to note the low coke deposition rates attained compared to those previously obtained for the supported ones (Table 2). Thus, the redox properties of CeO2 and its water adsorption capability are widely related to the attenuation of coke deposition in the literature [ 68,91 ]. Fig. 11 displays the TEM images of the used promoted catalysts. The three images show that the dark areas corresponding to Ni sites are partially encapsulated by amorphous coke. Besides, filamentous coke can also be observed, mainly in the case of Ni/CeO2-ZrO2. According to the results obtained in the TPO and TEM images, it can be corroborated that the high temperature peak in the TPO profile is related to the formation of the filamentous structure, which is the prevailing one in the case of the Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst. 4 Conclusions The strategy proposed for HDPE pyrolysis-OSR is a suitable alternative for obtaining H2 from plastics. Although slightly lower H2 production values than those in the conventional steam reforming are attained, it allows solving the main drawback of this route, which is energy integration into the process. Furthermore, operating under optimum conditions, H2 production is higher than that obtained with the alternative plastics gasification strategy, and a tar-free gas stream is obtained. The support used for Ni metal phase has a great influence on the activity of the oxidative steam reforming of HDPE pyrolysis volatile stream. Accordingly, the crystalline phases formed, and therefore the metal-support interactions, modify catalyst activity. Hence, the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst shows the best initial performance among the supported catalysts tested due to the weaker metal-support interactions in this catalyst, which lead to full reduction of NiO, thereby improving the availability of Ni0 metal active sites for the reforming reaction. Besides, the redox properties and O2 mobility of ZrO2 support enhance steam reforming and WGS reactions, and so the conversion of the HDPE pyrolysis volatile stream, as well as H2 production. Thus, although a space-time as low as 3.12 gcat min gHDPE −1 is used, a HDPE volatile conversion of 92.9% and a H2 production of 12.8 wt% were attained on the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst. Regarding the promoted catalysts tested (Ni/CeO2-Al2O3, Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 and Ni/CeO2-ZrO2), all of them show good performance for the OSR of HDPE pyrolysis volatiles, and the lower initial carbon conversion obtained than on supported catalysts is related to the lower reducibility of the Ni. Furthermore, the enhancement of water adsorption capacity by La2O3 addition leads to a higher activity of the Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 catalyst for WGS reaction, thus leading to a higher H2 production (12.1 wt%) than on the CeO2 promoted catalyst. The preliminary study conducted on catalysts deactivation shows that both the support and promoter play a key role on coke deposition, not only on the deposited coke amount, but also on its nature and location. Thus, the good performance of the prepared catalysts is an encouraging aspect for future studies on their stability, as well as deactivation by coke deposition, oxidation of the metal phase or sintering. In fact, the best catalyst must be chosen based on not only its initial activity, but also its stability and regeneration capacity when operation is conducted in successive reaction-regeneration cycles. coredata.dc:description: High density polyethylene (HDPE) pyrolysis and in-line oxidative steam reforming was carried out in a two-step reaction system consisting of a conical spouted bed reactor and a fluidized bed reactor. Continuous plastic pyrolysis was conducted at 550 °C and the volatiles formed were fed in-line to the oxidative steam reforming step (space-time 3.12 gcat min gHDPE −1; ER = 0.2 and steam/plastic = 3) operating at 700 °C. The influence Ni based reforming catalyst support (Al2O3, ZrO2, SiO2) and promoter (CeO2, La2O3) have on HDPE pyrolysis volatiles conversion and H2 production was assessed. The catalysts were prepared by the wet impregnation and they were characterized by means of N2 adsorption-desorption, X-ray fluorescence, temperature-programmed reduction and X-ray powder diffraction. A preliminary study on coke deposition and the deterioration of catalysts properties was carried out, by analyzing the tested catalysts through temperature programmed oxidation of coke, transmission electron microscopy, and N2 adsorption-desorption. Among the supports tested, ZrO2 showed the best performance, attaining conversion and H2 production values of 92.2% and 12.8 wt%, respectively. Concerning promoted catalysts, they led to similar conversion values (around 90%), but significant differences were observed in H2 production. Thus, higher H2 productions were obtained on the Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 catalyst (12.1 wt%) than on CeO2 promoted catalysts due to La2O3 capability for enhancing water adsorption on the catalyst surface.

coredata.dc:title: Oxidative steam reforming of HDPE pyrolysis volatiles on Ni catalysts: Effect of the support (Al2O3, ZrO2, SiO2) and promoter (CeO2, La2O3) on the catalyst performance
